questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of right-sided facial weakness and sound intolerance. Three days ago, he hit the right side of his head in a motor vehicle collision. He neither lost consciousness nor sought medical attention. Sensation over the face is not impaired. Impedance audiometry shows an absence of the acoustic reflex in the right ear. Which of the following muscles is most likely paralyzed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stylohyoid

 

The muscle most likely paralyzed in this patient is the stylohyoid. This is because the facial nerve (CN VII) innervates the muscles of facial expression and the stylohyoid, as well as the stapedius muscle, which is involved in the acoustic reflex. Facial nerve palsy leads to facial weakness and loss of the acoustic reflex, with normal facial sensation and preserved trigeminal (CN V) functions. The other muscles mentioned are not supplied by the facial nerve and would not be affected in this setting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tensor tympani: Supplied by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3), not the facial nerve. Paralysis would not result from facial nerve injury.

 

Option B. Posterior cricoarytenoid: This is a laryngeal muscle innervated by the recurrent laryngeal nerve (a branch of vagus, CN X), unrelated to facial nerve injury.

 

Option C. Stylopharyngeus: Supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), not the facial nerve and its function is to facilitate bolus of food- movement down the Pharynx.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the emergency department after a seizure. The patient reports pain on the left side of her face and is unable to fully open or close her mouth. She is drooling. On examination, the jaw deviates to the right and the left mandibular condyle is very prominent with a palpable depression posterior to it. The patient is diagnosed with an anterior dislocation of the left temporomandibular joint. The jaw is most likely maintained in a dislocated position due to continued spasm of which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lateral pterygoid

 

The muscle responsible for maintaining the jaw in an anteriorly dislocated temporomandibular joint (TMJ) position is the lateral pterygoid. Spasm of the lateral pterygoid pulls the mandibular condyle and articular disc anteriorly, preventing the jaw from closing properly in acute TMJ dislocation cases.

 

  • The lateral pterygoid muscle inserts onto the neck of the mandibular condyle and the articular disc, and its contraction produces forward (anterior) movement of the condyle.
  • When the mandible is dislocated anteriorly, the lateral pterygoid may enter into spasm and hold the condyle in the dislocated position, making reduction difficult until the spasm resolves

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Buccinator: Involved in cheek compression; does not move the condyle or disc of the TMJ.

 

Option B. Genioglossus: Primarily protrudes the tongue; not involved in TMJ articulation.

 

Option D. Sternocleidomastoid: Functions to turn and flex the neck; does not act on the mandible or TMJ

questions.text:
In which of the following vessels will the blood flow get affected if one puts a temporary clamp near the origin of the common hepatic artery?

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Right gastric
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Right gastroepiploic
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Replaced left hepatic
  4. ﻿﻿﻿Left gastroepiploic
  5. ﻿﻿﻿Left hepatic
  6. Superior pancreaticoduodenal
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 5, 6

 

To answer this question, we need to understand the branches of the common hepatic artery (CHA) and which downstream vessels would have their blood flow affected if a clamp is placed near its origin.

 

The common hepatic artery (CHA) is a branch of the celiac trunk and gives rise to the following major branches:

 

1. Proper hepatic artery, which then gives:

  • Right hepatic artery

→ Cystic artery

  • Left hepatic artery
  • Occasionally, right gastric artery arises here

2. Gastroduodenal artery, which gives:

  • Right gastroepiploic artery
  • Superior pancreaticoduodenal artery

 

Correct options:

 

1. Right gastric artery – Usually arises from the proper hepatic artery, a branch of CHA → Affected

 

2. Right gastroepiploic artery – Branch of gastroduodenal artery, which arises from CHA → Affected

 

5. Left hepatic artery – Usually a branch of proper hepatic artery → Affected 

 

6.Superior pancreaticoduodenal artery – Branch of gastroduodenal artery, which comes from CHA → Affected

 

Incorrect options:

 

3. Replaced left hepatic artery – If replaced, this means it arises not from CHA → Not affected

 

4. Left gastroepiploic artery – Arises from splenic artery, not from CHA → Not affected

questions.text: All of the following structures are approximately 25 cm in length except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transverse colon

 

The transverse colon is considerably longer than 25 cm, measuring on average 40–45 cm. It extends between the hepatic flexure and the splenic flexure, forming the longest and most mobile part of the colon. Because its length far exceeds 25 cm, it does not belong to the group of structures that are approximately 25 cm in size.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ureter: The ureter runs from the renal pelvis to the urinary bladder, with an average length of 25–30 cm. Its course is divided into abdominal, pelvic, and intramural parts, making it closely match the 25 cm standard.

 

Option B. Duodenum: The duodenum is about 25 cm long and forms a C-shaped loop around the head of the pancreas. It is the shortest yet widest part of the small intestine and is fixed retroperitoneally.

 

Option C. Esophagus: The esophagus extends from the pharynx to the stomach and measures around 25 cm. It passes through the thorax and diaphragm before entering the stomach, making it another structure that fits the 25 cm length group.

questions.text: Which of the following structure is affected in pancreas of a patient with Cystic Fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

Represents acini, which are classically affected in Cystic Fibrosis. Cystic Fibrosis results in mucous plugging and dilation in small and intralobular pancreatic ducts but the primary insult is in the acini. 

 

  • Leads to destruction and fibrosis of exocrine pancreatic tissue. 
  • Clinical sequelae include exocrine pancreatic insufficiency and, in advanced cases, involvement of islets.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Represents vessels which supply to Pancreas. Not primarily affected in pancreatic secretion stasis due to Cystic Fibrosis.

 

Option C. Shows pancreatic islets, which are not primarily affected in early CF. This structure of Pancreas is classically affected in DIABETES.

 

Option D. Represents Pancreatic duct, affected secondarily due to ductal obstruction [which is much later in course of time].

choices.text: Coronary sinus is guarded by the thebesian valve
Middle cardiac vein lies in the posterior atrioventricular groove
Great cardiac vein accompanies left anterior descending artery
Anterior cardiac vein opens into RA directly

questions.text: Which among the following is wrong about the venous drainage of the heart?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Middle cardiac vein leis in the posterior atrioventricular groove

 

The middle cardiac vein does not lie in the posterior atrioventricular groove. Instead, it runs in the posterior interventricular groove, accompanying the posterior interventricular (posterior descending) artery. Hence, the statement is wrong.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coronary sinus is guarded by the thebesian valve: True. The coronary sinus opens into the right atrium and its opening is partly guarded by a semicircular fold of endocardium called the Thebesian valve. Image demonstrates right atrium with the Thebesian valve partly covering the ostium of the coronary sinus

 

 

Option C. Great cardiac vein accompanies left anterior descending artery: True. The great cardiac vein ascends in the anterior interventricular groove along with the LAD artery, then curves around to drain into the coronary sinus.

 

Option D. Anterior cardiac vein opens into RA directly: True. The anterior cardiac veins drain blood from the right ventricle and open directly into the right atrium, bypassing the coronary sinus. It runs with Marginal artery [branch of RCA].

questions.text: A 66-year-old man hospitalized 3 days ago for left lower lobe pneumonia is evaluated for persistent fever. He has been receiving the appropriate intravenous antibiotics as determined by antibiotic susceptibility testing of his sputum cultures. The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension. His temperature is 38° C (100.4° F) and pulse is 87/min. Examination shows dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the left lower lung. Imaging studies reveal a loculated, left-sided pleural effusion. A tube is placed to drain the fluid via an incision at the 5th intercostal space in the midaxillary line. Which of the following muscles is most likely to be dissected during the procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serratus anterior

 

During insertion of a chest tube in the 5th intercostal space at the midaxillary line, the layers traversed include skin, subcutaneous tissue, serratus anterior muscle fibers, intercostal muscles, and finally the pleura. Serratus anterior lies along the lateral thoracic wall, covering the ribs in the midaxillary line, making it the key muscle dissected in this approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. External oblique: This muscle is part of the anterolateral abdominal wall, not involved in chest tube placement at the 5th intercostal space.

 

Option B. Latissimus dorsi: Though large and located on the posterior thorax, it is more posterior to the midaxillary line. Chest tube placement in the midaxillary region usually avoids this muscle.

 

Option C. Pectoralis major: This muscle lies on the anterior chest wall, covering the upper ribs. At the midaxillary line in the 5th intercostal space, it is not typically encountered.

 

Chest Tube insertion into the Triangle Of Safety:

questions.text: Which of the following types of joints is incorrectly matched?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sternoclavicular joint – Plane joint 

 

The sternoclavicular joint is not a plane joint. It is actually a saddle-type synovial joint that allows movement in multiple planes, though it functions almost like a ball-and-socket joint due to its wide range of motion. Hence, the given match is incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acromioclavicular joint – Plane synovial joint: Correct. The acromioclavicular joint is a plane-type synovial joint, permitting gliding movements between the acromion of the scapula and the clavicle.

 

Option B. Wrist joint – Condyloid joint: Correct. The wrist (radiocarpal) joint is a condyloid synovial joint, allowing flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, and circumduction.

 

Option D. Intercarpal joint – Plane synovial joint: Correct. The intercarpal joints between the carpal bones are plane-type synovial joints, allowing limited gliding movements.

questions.text: During a Forensic Medicine Conference, a detailed discussion is held on the mechanisms of death in cases of judicial hanging. One of the topics focuses on the anatomical structures involved in the upper cervical spine and their role in the cause of death when subjected to the forces involved in hanging. A case is presented where an individual subjected to judicial hanging was found to have significant cervical spine injuries during the autopsy. Based on the anatomical and forensic analysis, which of the following structures is most likely to be involved in causing death due to rupture in cases of judicial hanging?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Transverse Ligament of Dens 

 

In judicial hanging, the drop is designed to cause a sudden forceful hyperextension and distraction of the cervical spine, particularly around C1–C2 (atlas–axis). The transverse ligament of the dens is crucial for stabilizing the odontoid process (dens) of the axis against the anterior arch of the atlas. Its rupture leads to dislocation of the dens into the spinal cord, causing medullary compression and instant death. This is the most significant forensic finding in judicial hangings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Upper Band of Cruciate Ligament:

 

  • The upper band connects the dens to the occiput.
  • While it may be strained in cervical trauma, rupture is less commonly the direct cause of fatal instability compared to the transverse ligament.

 

Option B. Apical Ligament of Dens:

 

  • A weak midline structure that connects the dens to the anterior margin of the foramen magnum.
  • Not a major stabilizer of the atlantoaxial joint, so rupture alone is unlikely to cause death.

 

Option D. Membrana Tectoria:

 

  • This is a continuation of the posterior longitudinal ligament extending to the occipital bone.
  • It helps stabilize the craniocervical junction, rupture is not the key forensic mechanism in judicial hanging deaths.

questions.text: You should not insert the needle below which level in midaxillary line so as not to damage the liver?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 10th rib

 

In the midaxillary line, the right pleural cavity extends lower than the left due to the presence of the liver beneath the right dome of the diaphragm. The liver usually reaches up to the 10th rib in the midaxillary line.

 

  • Therefore, inserting a needle below the 10th rib in this line carries a significant risk of liver injury, especially during procedures like thoracocentesis or chest drain insertion.
  • To avoid damage, needle insertion is typically done above the rib margin (to avoid intercostal vessels) and usually around the 7th or 8th intercostal space in the midaxillary line.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 6th rib: This is too high; at this level, one is well within the lung fields. Risk to the liver is minimal here.

 

Option C. 8th rib: Safe zone often chosen for pleural aspiration in the midaxillary line. At this level, the liver lies lower, so the risk of puncture is less compared to going further down.

 

Option D. 12th rib: Much lower than the liver margin. By this level, you are in the abdominal region rather than the pleural cavity.

questions.text: In which layer of the cerebral cortex is the outer band of Baillarger seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Internal granular layer

 

The cerebral cortex has six layers (from superficial to deep). The outer band of Baillarger is a horizontal band of myelinated fibers found in the internal granular layer (Layer IV). This layer is particularly well-developed in the primary sensory cortex, where it receives thalamocortical afferents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. External pyramidal layer (Layer III):

 

  • Contains small to medium-sized pyramidal cells.
  • Involved in corticocortical connections but does not contain Baillarger’s bands.

 

Option C. Internal pyramidal layer (Layer V):

 

  • Contains large pyramidal cells (eg. Betz cells in motor cortex).
  • Associated with the inner band of Baillarger, not the outer band.

 

Option D. External granular layer (Layer II):

 

  • Contains small granular (stellate) cells.
  • Primarily involved in local intracortical connections, not Baillarger’s bands.

questions.text: Which of the following brainstem nuclei is not derived from the alar plate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypoglossal 

 

In embryology of the brainstem, the neural tube differentiates into two main plates:

 

  • Alar plate → sensory (afferent) nuclei.
  • Basal plate → motor (efferent) nuclei.

 

The hypoglossal nucleus is a motor nucleus located in the medulla and is derived from the basal plate, not the alar plate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inferior olivary nucleus:

 

  • Found in the medulla.
  • Derived from the alar plate (sensory/relay role).

 

Option B. Substantia nigra:

 

  • Located in the midbrain.
  • Functionally part of motor circuitry but embryologically considered alar plate derivative.

 

Option C. Dentate nucleus:

 

  • A deep cerebellar nucleus.
  • Also arises from the alar plate, which gives rise to cerebellar structures.

choices.text: Sensation in anterior scalp and dorsum of nose

questions.text: Sensation of which of the following structures are affected if a tumor or lesion compresses the structures passing through this opening of the skull marked A?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sensation in anterior scalp and dorsum of nose

 

The opening marked "A" in the image is the superior orbital fissure, which transmits structures including the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve (V1). If a tumor or lesion compresses the structures passing through the superior orbital fissure, the sensation in the anterior scalp and dorsum of nose (Option C. is affected, as these areas are supplied by branches of V1 (ophthalmic nerve).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sensation of nasopharynx: Supplied mainly by glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), not by divisions passing through the superior orbital fissure. Lesions here would affect swallowing and gag reflex, not facial sensation.

 

Option B. Mucosa of nasal cavity: Innervated by branches of the maxillary nerve (V2) through the sphenopalatine foramen. V2 passes via the foramen rotundum, not the superior orbital fissure.

 

Option D. Sensation of chin: Provided by the mental nerve, a branch of the mandibular division (V3) of trigeminal nerve. V3 exits through the foramen ovale, not the superior orbital fissure.

questions.text: Which of the following structures in women is homologous to gubernaculum testis in men?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Round ligament

 

The gubernaculum is a fibrous cord that guides the descent of the gonads during embryonic development.

 

  • In males, it persists as the gubernaculum testis, which anchors the testis within the scrotum.
  • In females, the gubernaculum does not shorten completely because the ovary stops in the pelvis (not descending into the labia). Its remnants form:
    • Round ligament of uterus → runs from uterus to labia majora via inguinal canal.
    • Ovarian ligament → connects ovary to uterus.

 

Thus, the round ligament of uterus is the homologue of gubernaculum testis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Broad ligament:

 

  • Not a gubernacular derivative.
  • It is a peritoneal fold, so it has no male homologue.

 

Option C. Uterosacral ligament:

 

  • Provides posterior support to uterus.
  • Homologue in male: Rectoprostatic fascia (Denonvilliers’ fascia), but not derived from gubernaculum.

 

Option D. Cardinal ligament (transverse cervical ligament):

 

  • Provides lateral support to uterus and cervix.
  • Homologue in male: Puboprostatic ligament (in pelvic fascia), again not related to gubernaculum.

questions.text: Superior gluteal nerve supplies all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Piriformis

 

The superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1) emerges through the greater sciatic foramen above the piriformis and supplies:

 

  • Gluteus medius
  • Gluteus minimus
  • Tensor fascia lata

 

These muscles are primarily responsible for thigh abduction and medial rotation, crucial in stabilizing the pelvis during walking.

 

  • The piriformis muscle, however, is supplied by the nerve to piriformis (a branch of the sacral plexus, S1–S2), not by the superior gluteal nerve. Action of Piriformis is Lateral Rotation Of Thigh.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of the nervous system, which of the following nerves can be tested by touching the highlighted structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IX

 

The highlighted structure in the image is the uvula (part of the soft palate).

 

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) provides sensory innervation (general sensation) to the posterior one-third of the tongue, pharynx, and soft palate (including uvula).
  • During clinical examination, touching the uvula or posterior pharyngeal wall elicits the gag reflex → sensory limb by CN IX, motor limb by CN X.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. X (Vagus nerve):

 

  • Provides motor innervation to most muscles of the pharynx and soft palate (except tensor veli palatini).
  • Responsible for the motor limb of the gag reflex and movement of uvula (deviation test).

 

Option C. XI (Accessory nerve):

 

  • Supplies sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.
  • Not involved in gag reflex or sensation of uvula. Tested by Shrugging of Shoulder against resistance. 

 

Option D. XII (Hypoglossal nerve):

 

  • Supplies intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue (except palatoglossus).
  • Tested by tongue protrusion, not by touching uvula.

questions.text: Match the following Subarachnoid Cisterns with their respective Vascular contents:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

 

The subarachnoid cisterns are enlargements of the subarachnoid space where cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) collects. Each cistern contains specific vascular structures.

 

A. Cisterna magna (cerebello-medullary cistern):

 

  • Located between the cerebellum and medulla.
  • Contains vertebral arteries and origin of posterior inferior cerebellar arteries (PICA).
  • Match → 2. Vertebral artery

 

B. Quadrigeminal cistern:

 

  • Located posterior to the colliculi and around the pineal gland.
  • Contains great cerebral vein (vein of Galen) and posterior cerebral arteries.
  • Match → 3. Vein of Galen

 

C. Sylvian cistern (lateral fissure cistern):

 

  • Located along the lateral sulcus between frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes.
  • Contains middle cerebral artery (MCA) and its branches.
  • Match → 4. MCA

 

D. Pontine cistern:

 

  • Located around the ventral surface of the pons.
  • Contains the basilar artery and origin of anterior inferior cerebellar arteries (AICA).
  • Match → 1. Basilar artery

choices.text: Hyperesthesia of the left ear lobe
Impaired taste of the posterior 1/3 of the tongue
Flushing of the right cheek while eating
Inability to wrinkle the left side of the forehead

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of increasing swelling in his left cheek and recurrent oral ulcers for 1 year. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Examination shows firm, nontender swelling above the angle of jaw. USG guided biopsy shows adenoid cystic carcinoma. A left sided total parotidectomy is performed. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inability to wrinkle the left side of the forehead

 

  • The parotid gland contains the branches of the facial nerve (CN VII), which pass through (but do not innervate) the gland.
  • During a total parotidectomy, there is a high risk of damaging the facial nerve or its branches.
  • The temporal branch of the facial nerve supplies the frontalis muscle, which wrinkles the forehead.
  • Hence, injury causes loss of forehead wrinkling on the operated side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperesthesia of the left ear lobe: Sensory supply to ear lobe is from great auricular nerve (C2–C3), not affected in parotidectomy.

 

Option B. Impaired taste of posterior 1/3 of tongue: This is mediated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), unrelated to parotidectomy.

 

Option C. Flushing of the right cheek while eating: 

 

  • This describes Frey’s syndrome (gustatory sweating and flushing), a complication of parotid surgery.
  • But it occurs on the operated side (left cheek here), not the opposite side (right cheek).

questions.text: Which of the following branches of internal Carotid artery are given off in the cervical region?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) None of the above 

 

The internal carotid artery (ICA) in the cervical region (from carotid bifurcation to carotid canal) travels without giving off any branches.

 

  • This is an important anatomical feature: no branches arise from ICA in the neck.
  • Its branches arise only after it enters the skull (petrous, cavernous, and cerebral parts).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pharyngeal branches: These are branches of the external carotid artery (not ICA).

 

Option B. Pterygoid branch: This comes from the maxillary artery, not from ICA.

 

Option C. Caroticotympanic branch: This is indeed a branch of the internal carotid artery, but it arises from the petrous part (intracranial), not the cervical part.

questions.text: Which of the following areas is not a part of anterior neck?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subclavian triangle

 

The anterior triangle of the neck is bounded by:

 

  • Lateral: Anterior border of sternocleidomastoid (SCM)
  • Medial: Midline of neck
  • Superior: Inferior border of mandible

 

It is further divided into four subdivisions:

 

  1. Submental triangle
  2. Digastric (Submandibular) triangle
  3. Carotid triangle
  4. Muscular triangle

 

The subclavian triangle, however, is part of the posterior triangle of the neck, not the anterior.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Submental triangle:

 

  • Lies beneath the chin.
  • Boundaries: anterior bellies of digastric muscles & hyoid bone.
  • Part of anterior triangle.

 

Option C. Digastric triangle (Submandibular):

 

  • Contains submandibular gland, facial artery & vein.
  • Part of anterior triangle.

 

Option D. Carotid triangle:

 

  • Contains carotid artery, IJV, vagus nerve, hypoglossal nerve.
  • Part of anterior triangle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Image given below shows Triangles of Neck:

choices.text: It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia
It lies anterior to the Poupart's ligament
It inserts into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon
Its fibers fan out with fascia illaca laterally

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the iliopubic tract?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Its fibers fan out with fascia illaca laterally

 

  • The iliopubic tract is a thickened inferior margin of the transversalis fascia.
  • It runs parallel and posterior-inferior to the inguinal ligament (Poupart’s ligament).
  • Laterally, it blends with the fascia iliaca, and medially, it attaches to the pubic bone.
  • It plays an important role in the posterior wall of the inguinal canal and is a landmark in laparoscopic hernia repair.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia: Incorrect. It is a thickening of the transversalis fascia, not lumbar fascia.

 

Option B. It lies anterior to the Poupart's ligament: Wrong. It actually lies posterior and inferior to the inguinal ligament (Poupart’s ligament).

 

Option C. It inserts into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon: No, it attaches to the iliopubic eminence and pubis, but not in front of the conjoint tendon.

questions.text: What level of the vertebral column does the given cross- sectional image correspond to:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) T9

 

Supportive anatomical points for T9 section

 

1] Liver and Stomach relationship

 

  • Large portion of the right lobe of liver is seen.
  • On the left side, the stomach (fundus/body region) is visible with air density.
  • This corresponds to the mid-thoracic level, around T9.

 

2] Esophagus

 

  • Seen as a circular structure close to midline, posterior to the left atrium, about to pass through the diaphragm at the esophageal hiatus (T10).
  • Thus, T9 is just above the esophageal opening

 

3] Lungs

 

  • Still visible here (lower lobes).
  • At T9 level, lungs are tapering off before ending at the costodiaphragmatic recess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T12: By this level, lungs and esophagus would no longer be seen; only abdominal structures (aortic hiatus, celiac trunk) appear.

 

Option B. T10: The esophagus would be entering the diaphragm (hiatus), lungs almost ending. The lungs in this image are more prominent, which fits T9 better.

 

Option D. T11: Esophagus would not be visible (already passed through diaphragm), lungs almost absent.

questions.text: The artery passing through the structure marked A is a branch of which part of the maxillary artery?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Third part

 

The image shows the sphenoid bone with its foramina.

 

  • Based on the location in the middle cranial fossa A = Vidian canal
  • Artery of pterygoid canal runs in the Vidian canal which arises from third part.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First part (mandibular part): 

 

  • Lies proximal to lateral pterygoid.
  • Branches: deep auricular, anterior tympanic, middle meningeal, accessory meningeal, inferior alveolar arteries.

 

Option B. Second part (pterygoid part):

 

  • Related to lateral pterygoid muscle.
  • Branches: masseteric, pterygoid, deep temporal, buccal arteries.

 

Option D. Fourth part:

 

  • No fourth part exists. Maxillary artery is classically divided into 3 parts only.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patients presents with hemiplegia on right side of body. On examination he was having loss of proprioception, fine touch and vibration sensations on right side. He was also unable to recognize the objects with closed eyes from right hand. On examination left side of the tongue was atrophied and deviation on left side during protrusion was found. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dejerine’s syndrome

 

The clinical features point to medial medullary involvement:

 

  1. Hemiplegia on right side → due to involvement of pyramidal tract (corticospinal fibers) in the medulla.
  2. Loss of proprioception, vibration, fine touch (right side) → due to lesion of medial lemniscus.
  3. Atrophy + deviation of tongue to left (ipsilateral) → due to involvement of hypoglossal nerve/nucleus (CN XII).

 

This classic triad = Dejerine’s syndrome (medial medullary syndrome).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parinaud’s syndrome:

 

  • Midbrain lesion (pineal tumor, dorsal midbrain).
  • Features: vertical gaze palsy, light-near dissociation of pupils, convergence-retraction nystagmus.
  • Not consistent with findings here.

 

Option B. Raymond’s syndrome:

 

  • Lesion in pons (ventral).
  • Causes contralateral hemiplegia + ipsilateral abducens (CN VI) palsy.
  • Tongue involvement (CN XII) is not seen.

 

Option D. Wallenberg’s syndrome (Lateral medullary syndrome):

 

  • Due to PICA occlusion.
  • Features: ipsilateral loss of pain/temp on face, contralateral pain/temp loss on body, ataxia, dysphagia, Horner’s syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not involved in the formation of the perineal body?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Internal anal sphincter muscle 

 

The perineal body is a central fibromuscular structure located at the midpoint of the perineum, between the anal canal and the urogenital structures. It serves as a convergence point for several perineal muscles, providing support to the pelvic floor.

 

Muscles attached to the perineal body include:

 

  • Bulbospongiosus muscle
  • Superficial transverse perineal muscles
  • Deep transverse perineal muscles[lie deep to sup.tran.perineii]
  • External anal sphincter
  • Levator ani (partially)

 

The central big black dot represents Perineal Body.

 

 

The internal anal sphincter, however, is not attached to the perineal body. It is a smooth muscle, an involuntary continuation of the inner circular layer of rectal smooth muscle, and does not contribute to perineal body formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bulbospongiosus muscle: Yes, contributes to perineal body. Helps in erection and ejaculation (male) and constriction of vaginal orifice (female).

 

Option B. Superficial transverse perineal muscles: Yes, these insert into the perineal body and help stabilize it.

 

Option C. Deep transverse perineal muscles: Yes, also insert into the perineal body, contributing to pelvic floor support.

questions.text: Which of the following structures of the inguinal canal lies outside the internal spermatic fascia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ilioinguinal nerve 

 

The inguinal canal contains different structures in males and females.

 

  • In males, it contains the spermatic cord + ilioinguinal nerve.
  • The spermatic cord is surrounded by three coverings derived from abdominal wall layers:
    1. External spermatic fascia (from external oblique aponeurosis)
    2. Cremasteric fascia & muscle (from internal oblique)
    3. Internal spermatic fascia (from transversalis fascia)

 

Structures like pampiniform plexus of veins, testicular artery, and testicular nerve plexus are inside the internal spermatic fascia because they are part of the spermatic cord.

 

The ilioinguinal nerve, however:

 

  • Enters the inguinal canal by piercing the internal oblique muscle.
  • Travels in the canal but does not pass through the deep inguinal ring, so it lies outside the internal spermatic fascia.
  • Provides sensory innervation to skin of upper medial thigh, root of penis, anterior scrotum/labia majora.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of post-styloid parapharyngeal space infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trismus

 

The parapharyngeal space is divided into two parts by the styloid process and its attached muscles/ligaments:

 

  1. Pre-styloid compartment → contains fat, lymph nodes, part of deep lobe of parotid.
  2. Post-styloid compartment → contains carotid sheath structures (ICA, IJV, cranial nerves IX, X, XI, XII, and sympathetic chain).

 

Trismus is typically seen in pre-styloid parapharyngeal space infection because of involvement of medial pterygoid muscle, not in post-styloid infections.

 

Infections in the post-styloid compartment therefore affect these structures.

 

  • Horner’s syndrome → due to involvement of cervical sympathetic chain.
  • Vocal cord palsy → due to vagus (CN X) involvement.
  • Parotid swelling → due to extension of infection to deep lobe of parotid.

choices.text: Splenorenal ligament – Splenic vessels and pancreatic tail

questions.text: All of the following peritoneal folds are correctly matched with their contents, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gastrocolic ligament – Right gastric artery

 

The peritoneal folds/ligaments are double layers of peritoneum that connect abdominal organs to each other or to the abdominal wall, and they transmit important vessels.

 

  • Gastrocolic ligament → part of the greater omentum; connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the transverse colon.
    • Contains right and left gastroepiploic vessels, not the right gastric artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Splenorenal ligament – Splenic vessels and pancreatic tail:

 

  • Correct. Connects spleen to posterior abdominal wall (over left kidney).
  • Transmits splenic artery, splenic vein, and tail of pancreas.

 

Option C. Transverse mesocolon – Middle colic vessels:

 

  • Correct. Suspends the transverse colon from the posterior abdominal wall.
  • Contains middle colic vessels.

 

Option D. Gastrosplenic ligament – Short gastric vessels:

 

  • Correct. Connects stomach to spleen.
  • Contains short gastric vessels and left gastroepiploic vessels.

questions.text: During surgery on a 56-year-old man for a squamous cell carcinoma of the neck, the surgeon notices profuse bleeding from the deep cervical artery. Which of the following arteries must be ligated immediately to stop bleeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Costocervical trunk

 

  • The deep cervical artery is a branch of the costocervical trunk, which arises from the second part of the subclavian artery (posterior to the anterior scalene).
  • In case of profuse bleeding from the deep cervical artery, the surgeon must ligate the costocervical trunk to control it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inferior thyroid artery:

 

  • Branch of the thyrocervical trunk.
  • Supplies thyroid gland and related structures.
  • Not related to the deep cervical artery.

Option B. Transverse cervical artery:

 

  • Also a branch of the thyrocervical trunk.
  • Supplies trapezius and posterior scapular region.
  • Not the source of the deep cervical artery.

 

Option C. Thyrocervical trunk:

 

  • Branch of the first part of subclavian artery.
  • Gives rise to inferior thyroid, transverse cervical, suprascapular arteries.
  • Does not give deep cervical artery.

questions.text: Third part of vertebral artery is related to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2

 

The third part of the vertebral artery is related to the posterior arch of Atlas, which is marked as 2 in the image.

 

  • The vertebral artery's third part runs in a groove on the superior surface of the posterior arch of Atlas (C1), before entering the foramen magnum.

questions.text: The hepatic sinusoids that can be observed histologically in an adult liver are derived from the?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitelline veins

 

  • The vitelline veins are paired embryonic veins that return blood from the yolk sac to the sinus venosus.
  • During development, they undergo extensive remodeling around the developing hepatic cords.
  • This remodeling gives rise to:
    • Hepatic sinusoids
    • Hepatic segment of inferior vena cava (IVC)
    • Portal vein and its tributaries
    • Part of hepatic veins

 

Thus, the hepatic sinusoids in the adult liver are derived from the vitelline veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supracardinal veins:

 

  • Contribute to the azygos and hemiazygos venous system.
  • Not related to hepatic sinusoids.

 

Option B. Anterior cardinal veins:

 

  • Form the internal jugular veins and contribute to the superior vena cava.
  • Not involved in liver development.

 

Option D. Subcardinal veins:

 

  • Contribute to the renal veins, gonadal veins, and suprarenal veins, as well as part of the IVC.
  • Not the source of hepatic sinusoids.

questions.text: Which of the following structures do not pass through both greater and lesser sciatic foramens?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tendon of obturator internus

 

It does not pass through both the greater and lesser sciatic foramina—it passes only through the lesser sciatic foramen.

 

  • Pudendal nerve, nerve to obturator internus, and internal pudendal vessels exit the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen, loop around the ischial spine, and re-enter the perineum via the lesser sciatic foramen.
  • The tendon of obturator internus passes only through the lesser sciatic foramen, entering the gluteal region

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the OPD due to occasional dull headaches that awaken him from sleep. The patient has no associated neurologic deficits. On physical examination, there are several 3 cm to 5 cm flat, pigmented spots on his trunk. There are also multiple, subcentimeter, soft, fleshy, cutaneous tumors located on his trunk and neck. The predominant cells forming these tumors most likely originated from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neural crest

 

This patient's findings (multiple cutaneous neurofibromas and café-au-lait spots) are classic for Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). The predominant cells forming neurofibromas (Schwann cells) originate from the neural crest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoderm:

 

  • Gives rise to epithelial lining of GI tract, respiratory tract, and associated glands.
  • Does not contribute to cutaneous tumors or neural tissue.
  • Unrelated to the pathogenesis of neurofibromas.

 

Option B. Mesoderm:

 

  • Forms muscle, bone, connective tissue, and blood vessels.
  • Not the source of Schwann cells or melanocytes in skin lesions.
  • Provides structural support but not the neural elements here.

 

Option D. Neural tube:

 

  • Gives rise to central nervous system neurons and glial cells.
  • Does not form peripheral nerves or Schwann cells.
  • Involved in CNS but not in cutaneous neurofibromas.

questions.text: A 1-week-old boy is brought to the emergency department with poor feeding, lethargy, and unusual "muscle movements" involving the left thumb and hand over the last 2 days. The infant's vital signs are normal, but unusual flexion of the left wrist and thumb and extension of the fingers are observed with cuff blood pressure measurement. Physical examination reveals a hypoplastic mandible, low-set ears, bifid uvula, and cleft palate. A chest x-ray is shown below.These findings most likely suggest impaired development of which of the following embryonic structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Third pharyngeal pouch

 

This case describes a neonate with congenital anomalies (facial dysmorphisms, cleft palate), carpopedal spasm with BP cuff inflation (Trousseau sign—indicative of hypocalcemia), and a chest X-ray showing absent thymic shadow. These findings are characteristic of DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion syndrome), involving defective development of the third (and fourth) pharyngeal pouch.

 

  • The third pharyngeal pouch gives rise to the inferior parathyroids and thymus. Failure of this pouch leads to hypocalcemia (hypoparathyroidism) and immunodeficiency (thymic aplasia, absent thymic shadow).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foramen cecum: Located at the junction of the tongue and oral cavity; it marks the origin of the thyroid diverticulum. Has no role in thymus or parathyroid gland development. Defects cause thyroid abnormalities (e.g., ectopic thyroid).

 

Option C. Rathke pouch: An ectodermal outpouching from the roof of the oral cavity; gives rise to the anterior pituitary (adenohypophysis). Defects affect pituitary hormone production.

 

Option D. Second pharyngeal cleft: Usually obliterated during development; persists as branchial cyst if not. Defects result in lateral neck cysts, not immunodeficiency or hypocalcemia.

questions.text: Identify the incorrectly matched pair with respect to its nerve supply of the marked structures in the given image:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glossopharyngeal nerve

 

The muscle marked by C is Geniohyoid , supplied by hypoglossal nerve via C1 cervical root.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial nerve: Platysma – Supplied by Facial nerve

 

Option B. Trigeminal nerve: Digastric[ant belly] – Supplied by Mandibular nerve[V3]

 

Option D. Hypoglossal nerve: Supplied by Hypoglossal nerv

choices.text: Lies in front of the transverse process of the sixth cervical vertebra
Blocking this point leads to weakness of sternocleidomastoid
Landmark in the neck where the spinal accessory nerve emerges into the posterior triangle
Formed by the C5 and C6 nerve roots, and the cutaneous branches of the cervical plexus

questions.text: All of the following are true about the marked point except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blocking this point leads to weakness of sternocleidomastoid

 

Blocking Erb's point does not cause weakness of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, as the sternocleidomastoid is mainly supplied by the spinal accessory nerve (cranial nerve XI), which is not blocked at this point.

The marked point in the image is Erb's point (nerve point of the neck), where several cutaneous branches of the cervical plexus emerge.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lies in front of the transverse process of the sixth cervical vertebra: True. Erb's point lies in front of the transverse process of the sixth cervical vertebra.

 

Option C. Landmark in the neck where the spinal accessory nerve emerges into the posterior triangle: True. This is a landmark where the spinal accessory nerve emerges into the posterior triangle.

 

Option D. Formed by the C5 and C6 nerve roots, and the cutaneous branches of the cervical plexus: True. Erb's point is formed by the convergence of C5 and C6 nerve roots and cutaneous branches of the cervical plexus (lesser occipital, great auricular, transverse cervical, and supraclavicular nerves).

choices.text: Transverse sinus is between arterial and venous pericardial reflection.
Oblique sinus lies behind left atrium
Transverse sinus lies behind ascending aorta
Oblique sinus allows a surgeon to ligate the pulmonary vessels

questions.text: Which of the following is accurate regarding pericardial sinuses?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oblique sinus allows a surgeon to ligate the pulmonary vessels 

 

It is the transverse sinus, not the oblique, that is surgically important for ligating great vessels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transverse sinus is between arterial and venous pericardial reflection: Transverse sinus is between arterial and venous pericardial reflection

 

Option C. Transverse sinus lies anterior to SVC: Correct. It lies anterior to SVC and posterior to aorta and pulmonary trunk, not strictly "behind the aorta."

questions.text: Which muscle is physically in the back but functionally in the thorax?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Levator costae

 

The levator costarum (levator costae) muscles are small, paired muscles located in the back, arising from the transverse processes of vertebrae and inserting onto the ribs below.

 

  • Anatomical position: They are in the back (dorsal region).
  • Functional role: They elevate the ribs during inspiration, thereby assisting the thoracic cage in respiration.
  • Hence, though physically present in the back, they are functionally muscles of the thorax.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rhomboid:

 

  • Located in the back.
  • Function: retract and stabilize the scapula.
  • Not functionally related to thorax.

 

Option B. Latissimus dorsi:

 

  • Large back muscle.
  • Function: adduction, extension, medial rotation of humerus.
  • Not related to respiration.

 

Option C. Trapezius:

 

  • Large superficial back muscle.
  • Function: elevates, retracts, rotates scapula.
  • Not involved in thoracic function.

questions.text: At which of the following levels does an inverted Supinator jerk indicate a lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) C5, C6

 

The supinator jerk (brachioradialis reflex) is elicited by tapping the tendon of the brachioradialis muscle near the wrist.

 

  • Normal response → flexion & supination of forearm.
  • This reflex tests the C5–C6 spinal segments, mainly radial nerve function.

 

An inverted supinator jerk means:

 

  • When the reflex is elicited, instead of forearm flexion/supination, there is finger flexion due to overactivity of finger flexors.
  • This indicates an upper motor neuron lesion at C5–C6, with sparing of lower segments (C7–T1).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. C6, C7:

 

  • Associated more with triceps reflex.
  • Not responsible for inverted supinator jerk.

 

Option C. L5, S1:

 

  • Involved in ankle jerk reflex.
  • Not related to supinator reflex.

 

Option D. L4, S1:

 

  • Combination not relevant; knee jerk is L3–L4, ankle jerk L5–S1.

questions.text: All of the following form boundaries of quadrangular space except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supraspinatus

 

The quadrangular space is an important anatomical space in the posterior shoulder region that allows passage of the axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral artery.

 

Its boundaries are:

 

  • Superior: Teres minor
  • Inferior: Teres major
  • Medial: Long head of triceps
  • Lateral: Surgical neck of humerus

 

 

Supraspinatus does not take part in forming this space. It is located superiorly in the supraspinous fossa and is related to the suprascapular notch, not the quadrangular space.

questions.text: The caecum is found to be placed below the stomach and is midline. Which of the following abnormalities must have taken place while rotation of the gut?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mixed Rotation 

 

During embryological development, the midgut rotates 270° counterclockwise around the superior mesenteric artery (SMA).

 

  • Normal rotation: places the caecum in the right lower quadrant.
  • Mixed rotation: part of the midgut rotates normally, while another part malrotates. This can result in abnormal positioning such as the caecum lying below the stomach, in the midline.
    • It is a combination of malrotation and nonrotation features.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malrotation:

 

  • Incomplete rotation of midgut.
  • Caecum may lie in subhepatic region (right upper quadrant), not below stomach in midline.

 

Option B. Nonrotation:

 

  • Midgut fails to rotate the final 180°.
  • Caecum ends up on the left side of abdomen, not midline.

 

Option C. Reverse rotation:

 

  • Midgut rotates in the clockwise direction instead of counterclockwise.
  • Leads to duodenum lying anterior to SMA and transverse colon posterior to SMA.
  • Not associated with caecum lying below the stomach.

questions.text: The hormone produced and released by the cell at the tip of the arrow binds to receptors on the surface of which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteoclast

 

The cell at the tip of the arrow is a parathyroid chief cell, which produces parathyroid hormone (PTH). PTH ultimately acts to increase blood calcium by stimulating osteoclasts—cells responsible for bone resorption.

 

  • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) binds to receptors (via the RANK/RANKL pathway, indirectly mediated by osteoblasts) that activate osteoclasts, leading to increased bone resorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoblasts: Osteoblasts possess PTH receptors. PTH binding induces them to express RANKL, stimulating osteoclast differentiation. They do not resorb bone directly; they build bone matrix.

 

Option B. Chondrocytes: Chondrocytes are cartilage cells involved in cartilage formation/growth. 

 

Option C. Osteocytes: Osteocytes are mature bone cells embedded in bone matrix, functioning in bone maintenance and mineral homeostasis. They do not express PTH receptors for bone resorption.

questions.text: Which is the last fontanelle to close?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior

 

The fontanelles are membranous gaps between the skull bones in infants that allow brain growth and facilitate childbirth. Their closure times are clinically important.

 

  • Anterior fontanelle (bregmatic):
    • Largest fontanelle (diamond-shaped).
    • Closes last, usually by 18–24 months of age.
  • Posterior fontanelle (lambdoid/occipital):
    • Small, triangular.
    • Closes by 2–3 months.
  • Mastoid fontanelle:
    • At junction of squamous temporal, parietal, and occipital bones.
    • Closes by 6–18 months.
  • Sphenoidal (anterolateral) fontanelle:
    • At junction of frontal, parietal, sphenoid, and temporal bones.
    • Closes by 6 months.

questions.text: A woman receives an injection of a radio- isotope to determine regional blood flow in the brain. She has a positron emission tomography scan to visualize variations in cortical blood flow. The examiner asks her to think about flexing her index finger without actually doing it. In which of the following cortical areas would you expect to see increased blood flow?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supplementary motor cortex

 

When a person is asked to think about movement (motor imagery), but not actually perform it:

 

  • The supplementary motor area (SMA), located on the medial surface of the frontal lobe (anterior to primary motor cortex), shows increased activity.
  • SMA is involved in planning, programming, and initiation of voluntary movements, especially when imagining or preparing to move.
  • In contrast, the primary motor cortex (motor strip) is activated during actual execution of the movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Angular gyrus:

 

  • Located in the parietal lobe.
  • Involved in language, number processing, and spatial cognition.
  • Not related to motor planning.

 

Option B. Motor strip (Primary motor cortex, M1):

 

  • Controls execution of voluntary movement.
  • Would be activated if she actually flexed her finger, not just thought about it.

 

Option C. S-I somatosensory cortex:

 

  • Processes tactile and proprioceptive input.
  • Not directly involved in planning or imagining movement.

questions.text:
Match the following:

 

  1. Stimulation of this area results in turning the eyes and head to the contralateral side
  2. A lesion here results in nonfluent, telegraphic speech
  3. Ablation in this area results in a contralateral upper homonymous quadrantanopia
  4. A lesion here results in fluent speech with neologisms
  5. A lesion of this area is characterized by finger agnosia, dyscalculia, dysgraphia, and dyslexia
  6. Destruction of this area results in an aphasia characterized by fluent speech, good com- prehension, and poor repetition
  7. Lesions in this gyrus result in contralateral astereognosis
  8. Lesions in this gyrus result in contralateral spasticity
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-H, 2-G, 3-F, 4-E, 5-D, 6-C ,7-B, 8-A

 

The correct matching of numbered clinical findings to the labeled areas on the brain diagram as per the answer and options is:

 

  1. Stimulation of this area results in turning the eyes and head to the contralateral side
     — H. Frontal eye field
  2. A lesion here results in nonfluent, telegraphic speech
     — G. Broca’s area
  3. Ablation in this area results in a contralateral upper homonymous quadrantanopia
     — F. Inferior portion of the optic radiation (Meyer’s loop/temporal lobe)
  4. A lesion here results in fluent speech with neologisms
     — E. Wernicke’s area
  5. A lesion of this area is characterized by finger agnosia, dyscalculia, dysgraphia, and dyslexia
     — D. Angular gyrus
  6. Destruction of this area results in an aphasia characterized by fluent speech, good comprehension, and poor repetition
     — C. Arcuate fasciculus
  7. Lesions in this gyrus result in contralateral astereognosis
     — B. Somatosensory cortex (postcentral gyrus)
  8. Lesions in this gyrus result in contralateral spasticity
     — A. Precentral gyrus (primary motor cortex)

questions.text: The diameter of the structure in the picture taken from a dead male is 3.1 cm. What is the name of the autosomal recessive trait that this person evidenced?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mounier-Kuhn syndrome

 

The structure in the image is likely a trachea or bronchus. A diameter of 3.1 cm is abnormally dilated. This, in combination with the inheritance pattern (autosomal recessive), is characteristic of Mounier-Kuhn syndrome (tracheobronchomegaly).

 

Mounier-Kuhn syndrome is a rare genetic disorder resulting in marked dilatation of the trachea and main bronchi due to atrophy of elastic and smooth muscle fibers, leading to recurrent respiratory infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spontaneous pneumothorax: Associated with ruptured blebs, not airways dilatation. Associated with Marfan disease[Autosomal Dominant].

 

Option B. Asbestosis: Pneumoconiosis with fibrosis, not airway dilatation. Commonly affects basal lobes

 

Option C. Emphysema: Destruction of alveolar walls, can cause bullae but not enlarged trachea/bronchi. It is a part of spectrum of COPD.

questions.text:
Match the following:

 

 

  1. Rupture of the tendon superior to this structure would most likely cause an inability to extend the knee joint.
  2. Fracture of this structure would most likely cause weakness in adduction of the thigh.
  3. A knife penetrating through this point would most likely cause muscle ischemia in the anterior compartment of the leg.
  4. Fracture of this structure would most likely cause impaired dorsiflexion of foot
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-C, 2-A, 3-B, 4-E

 

  • 1 → C (patella)
    Rupture of the quadriceps tendon (superior to the patella) → inability to extend the knee.
  • 2 → A (medial femoral condyle/adductor tubercle)
    Fracture here disrupts attachment of the adductor magnus tendon → weak thigh adduction.
  • 3 → B (proximal interosseous gap region)
    A stab here can injure the anterior tibial artery as it passes through the proximal opening in the interosseous membrane → ischemia of the anterior compartment.
  • 4 → E (neck of fibula)
    Fracture at the fibular neck endangers the common fibular nerve → foot drop with impaired dorsiflexion (deep fibular nerve).

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman has a history of infection in her perineal region. A comprehensive examination reveals a tear of the superior boundary of the superficial perineal space. Which of the following structures would most likely be injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Perineal membrane

 

The superficial perineal space (pouch) is a potential space in the urogenital triangle.

 

  • Boundaries:
    • Superior (roof): Perineal membrane (a tough fascial sheet).
    • Inferior (floor): Colles’ fascia (superficial perineal fascia).
    • Laterally: Ischiopubic rami.

 

Therefore, if the superior boundary is torn, the injured structure is the perineal membrane.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pelvic diaphragm:

 

  • Located much deeper (levator ani + coccygeus).
  • Forms the floor of the pelvic cavity, not a boundary of superficial perineal pouch.

 

Option B. Colles fascia:

 

  • Inferior boundary (floor) of superficial perineal pouch.

 

Option C. Deep perineal fascia:

 

  • Covers superficial perineal muscles (e.g., ischiocavernosus, bulbospongiosus).
  • Not the boundary of the space.

questions.text:
Match the descriptions in items 1 to 5 with the appropriate lettered lesion in the diagram of a cross-section of the spinal cord.

  1. Ipsilateral lower limb dystaxia
  2. Ipsilateral flaccid paralysis
  3. Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation one segment below the lesion
  4. Exaggerated muscle stretch reflexes below the lesion
  5. Loss of two-point tactile discrimination in the ipsilateral foot
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-B, 2-D, 3-E, 4-C, 5-A

 

Here are the correct matches for the spinal cord cross-section lesions:

 

  1. Ipsilateral lower limb dystaxia
     B (Lateral/Posterior Cerebellar Tract—dorsal spinocerebellar tract)
  2. Ipsilateral flaccid paralysis
     D (Anterior Horn—lower motor neuron lesion)
  3. Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation one segment below the lesion
     E (Spinothalamic Tract—crosses over within 1-2 segments)
  4. Exaggerated muscle stretch reflexes below the lesion
     C (Corticospinal Tract—upper motor neuron lesion)
  5. Loss of two-point tactile discrimination in the ipsilateral foot
     A (Posterior Columns—gracile fasciculus)

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital with severe head injuries after a car crash. During neurologic examination her uvula is found to be deviated to the right. Which nerve is most likely affected to result in this deviation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left vagus

 

A lesion of the left vagus nerve will cause the uvula to deviate to the right. The muscles of the soft palate innervated by the vagus nerve elevate the palate; if one side (left) is paralyzed, the palate is pulled up by the healthy side (right), causing the uvula to deviate toward the right.

 

Rule of 17:

 

  • 10 and 7 cause contralateral deviation-{10 and contra both have o in them, if one is 10 other should be 7 = nmemonic}
  • 5 and 12 cause ipsilateral deviation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right vagus: A lesion of the right vagus would cause the uvula to deviate to the left (toward the healthy side), not the right.

 

Option C. Left glossopharyngeal: Glossopharyngeal nerve lesions affect sensation to the posterior third of the tongue and oropharynx, but do not cause uvular deviation.

 

Option D. Right glossopharyngeal: Similar to the left, would affect taste/sensation, but would not result in uvular deviation.

questions.text: A chest CT scan is performed on a 35-year-old man who presented with chronic cough and weight loss. Which of the following structures labelled below is a derivative of the common cardinal veins?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

The anatomical structure labeled A in the CT scan is the superior vena cava, which is a direct derivative of the common cardinal veins during embryological development.

 

A: The right common cardinal vein and the right anterior cardinal vein unite to form the superior vena cava, an essential embryological remnant in the adult venous system.

 

B. It is the aorta (ascending/arch), derived from the embryonic truncus arteriosus and aortic arches.

 

C. It is  the pulmonary artery arch, develops from the truncus arteriosus and aortic arches, not from cardinal veins.

 

D. It is Esophagus. The esophagus develops from the anterior foregut during the early weeks of gestation.

 

E. It is Descending Aorta, continuation of Aortic Arch.

questions.text: The given condition is due to persistence of which of the following embryonic vessel?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Persistence of right dorsal aorta

 

The finding described (vascular ring or double aortic arch) is due to the persistence of the right dorsal aorta. This results in a vascular anomaly where the right dorsal aorta fails to regress during development, creating a ring around the trachea and esophagus.

 

  • This anomaly can compress the airway or esophagus, leading to symptoms like chronic cough, dysphagia, or stridor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Persistence of left 4th arch artery: Forms part of the definitive aortic arch (normal development). The left 4th aortic arch gives rise to the arch of aorta between the left common carotid and left subclavian arteries.

 

Option C. Persistence of left dorsal aorta: Forms the descending aorta. Persistence is normal and does not result in vascular anomalies.

 

Option D. Persistence of left 6th arch artery: Gives rise to the ductus arteriosus and pulmonary arteries on the left side. Persistence causes patent ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: Fibres from mamillary bodies terminate at which of the following points?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

Fibers from the mammillary bodies (mammillothalamic tract, part of the Papez circuit) terminate at the anterior nucleus of the thalamus.

 

In the illustration, A represents the anterior nucleus of the thalamus, the correct termination point for mammillary body fibers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. B→ Ventro-anterior (VA) nucleus: 

 

  • Function: Motor relay.
  • Connections: Receives input from basal ganglia (globus pallidus) → projects to premotor cortex.

 

Option C. C → Ventro-lateral (VL) nucleus:

 

  • Function: Motor relay.
  • Connections: Receives input from cerebellum & basal ganglia → projects to primary motor cortex.

 

Option D. D → Ventro-posterior lateral (VPL) nucleus:

 

  • Function: Somatosensory relay (body).

 

Connections: Receives medial lemniscus & spinothalamic tract → projects to primary somatosensory cortex.

questions.text: Area marked A in the given figure contain all the following, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zonula occludens

 

The area marked A in the image is an intercalated disc of cardiac muscle, which contains

 

Zonula occludens (tight junction) is NOT found in cardiac intercalated discs.

 

Zonula occludens (tight junctions) are specialized connections at the apical surface of epithelial cells that create a seal, preventing passage of substances between adjacent cells. They help maintain cell polarity and tissue compartmentalization. Tight junctions are primarily composed of proteins like claudins and occludin. They are essential for barrier functions in organs such as the intestines and kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

An intercalated disc of cardiac muscle contains:

 

Option B. Zonula adherens (intermediate junction): present in the transverse portion of the disc, provides mechanical linkage.

 

Option C. Macula adherens (desmosome): provides spot adhesions for structural integrity.

 

Option D. Gap junction: facilitates electrical impulse propagation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zonula occludens comprises the tight junctions constituted by members of the transmembrane claudin, occluding, and JAM proteins.

questions.text: All of the following structures lie in the relation to the left ureter except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Quadratus lumborum

 

The ureter descends from the renal pelvis to the bladder, and along its course, it has important anatomical relations. Quadratus lumborum is more lateral in position, and the ureter lies directly on the psoas major, not quadratus lumborum. Hence, quadratus lumborum is not in relation to the ureter.

 

Relations of the left ureter:

 

  • Posteriorly (lumbar part): Psoas major, bifurcation of common iliac artery.
  • Medially: Inferior mesenteric vessels, sigmoid colon & its mesentery, sigmoidal veins.
  • Anteriorly: Left colic vessels, left testicular/ovarian vessels, root of sigmoid mesocolon.

questions.text:
Identify the synovial joints:

 

  1. Costotransverse joint

  2. Costovertebral joint

  3. Costo-chondral joints

  4. 2nd Sternocostal joint

  5. Sternoclavicular joint
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4, 5

 

Synovial joints → freely movable joints with a synovial cavity, synovial membrane, articular cartilage, and joint capsule.

 

Statement 1. Costotransverse joint: Synovial (plane type) between tubercle of rib and transverse process of vertebra. 

 

Statement 2. Costovertebral joint: Synovial (plane type) between head of rib and body of vertebrae. 

 

Statement 3. Costo-chondral joints: Primary cartilaginous joints (synchondroses) between rib and its costal cartilage. 

 

Statement 5. Sternoclavicular joint: Synovial (saddle type) with an articular disc. 

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Statement 4. 2nd Sternocostal joint: Synovial (plane type) → exception, as 1st sternocostal is primary cartilaginous.

choices.text: Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib

questions.text: Which among the following is incorrect regarding Sibsons's fascia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib

 

Sibson’s fascia (also called the suprapleural membrane) is a specialized thickening of the endothoracic fascia at the thoracic inlet.

 

  • Attachments:
    • Laterally → inner border of 1st rib & its costal cartilage (not 2nd rib).
    • Medially → tip of transverse process of C7 vertebra.
  • Relations[Other Options:]
    • Covers the apex of the lung and cervical pleura, preventing bulging into the root of the neck.
    • Considered a derivative of the scalenus minimus muscle (when present).
    • Subclavian vessels and branches of brachial plexus pass above the fascia.

questions.text: A patient presents with a unilateral throbbing headache, photophobia, and excessive lacrimation. He also complains of hemifacial pain on clenching of teeth. On examination, pupillary reflex, light reflex, and accommodation reflex are normal. Which of the following marked nerves is involved in the above scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3

 

It is mandibular nerve (V3) passing through the foramen ovale. Diagnosis is Trigeminal neuralgia (tic douloureux) involving the mandibular division (V3).

 

  • Hemifacial pain on clenching teeth points to involvement of V3, which carries sensory fibers from the lower face/teeth and motor fibers to the muscles of mastication (clenching aggravates pain).
  • Normal pupillary, light, and accommodation reflexes make cranial nerves II, III, and the parasympathetic pathway to the eye unlikely.
  • Lacrimation may be reflex/associated autonomic accompaniment of trigeminal pain and does not require ocular parasympathetic involvement to be abnormal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1. (Optic nerve): Involved in light reflex 

 

Option B. 2. (Abducens nerve): muscle for eye movement.

 

Option D. 4. (Facial nerve): supplies facial muscles.

questions.text: All the following form the marked structure except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2nd Palmar interossei

 

The marked structure in the image is the extensor expansion (dorsal digital expansion/extensor hood) of the finger.

 

It is formed by:

 

  • Extensor digitorum
  • Lumbricals
  • Dorsal interossei (including 2nd)
    but not by the 2nd palmar interossei (which is absent on the middle finger)

questions.text: Which nerve injury is most likely responsible for the observed symptoms of foot?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Common peroneal nerve

 

The image shows "foot drop," where the affected foot cannot be dorsiflexed and appears to hang limp. This is most commonly caused by injury to the common peroneal (fibular) nerve, which innervates the muscles responsible for dorsiflexion and toe extension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Femoral nerve: Injury leads to weakness of knee extension (quadriceps) and sensory loss over the anterior thigh and medial leg, not foot drop.

 

Option C. Sciatic nerve: Injury produces loss of all functions below the knee (including foot drop), plus loss of plantar flexion and knee flexion. There would be a more flaccid, overall paralyzed lower limb.

 

Option D. Tibial nerve: Injury causes loss of plantar flexion and inversion of the foot, resulting in dorsiflexed/"calcaneovalgus" foot, not foot drop.

choices.text: Present medial to white rami communicantes

questions.text: All of the following are true about grey rami communicantes except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Preganglionic

 

Grey rami contain postganglionic, not preganglionic, fibers.

 

Rami communicantes are connections between the spinal nerves and the sympathetic chain.

 

  • White rami communicantes
    • Contain preganglionic sympathetic fibers (myelinated).
    • Present only at T1–L2 spinal levels (thoracolumbar outflow).
  • Grey rami communicantes
    • Contain postganglionic sympathetic fibers (unmyelinated).
    • Present at all spinal levels, because sympathetic supply must reach the entire body.
    • They connect the sympathetic ganglia back to the spinal nerves.
    • Usually lie medial to white rami.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unmyelinated: True. Grey rami carry postganglionic unmyelinated fibers.

 

Option B. Connected to spinal nerve: True. They rejoin the spinal nerve to distribute sympathetic fibers.

 

Option D. Present medial to white rami communicantes: True in relation to sympathetic chain.

questions.text: Which is not a branch of the vessel known as the Anesthetist’s artery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mental

 

The anesthetist’s artery refers to the facial artery, an important branch of the external carotid artery. It is clinically significant because of its use in anesthesia and its tortuous course around the face. 

 

The Mental artery is not a branch of the facial artery. It is a terminal branch of the inferior alveolar artery (from maxillary artery), which exits the mental foramen to supply the chin and lower lip.

 

Branches of the facial artery (extracranial part):

 

  • Cervical branches: Ascending palatine, tonsillar, submental, glandular branches.
  • Facial branches:
    • Inferior labial artery
    • Superior labial artery
    • Lateral nasal artery
    • Angular artery (terminal branch)

questions.text: The blood oxygen saturations measured from different fetal vessel samples are 71%, 64%, 62%, 55%, and 43%. The sample with the greatest oxygen saturation was most likely obtained from which of the following blood vessels?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior vena cava

 

In the fetus, oxygenation occurs in the placenta, not the lungs. Oxygen-rich blood returns via the umbilical vein (≈80% saturation). This blood partially bypasses the liver through the ductus venosus and joins the inferior vena cava (IVC), which therefore carries the highest oxygen saturation (around 70–75%).

 

Oxygen saturation in various fetal vessels:

 

  • Umbilical vein → ~80% (highest, but not in options here).
  • Inferior vena cava (just above ductus venosus entry) → ~70–75%.
  • Right atrium (mixed) → ~62–65%.
  • Pulmonary trunk → ~55–60%.[option D]
  • Ductus arteriosus → ~55–60%.[option B]
  • Descending aorta (distal) → ~45–55%.[option A]

questions.text: The structure marked in the image is embedded in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral head of gastrocnemius

 

The structure marked by the arrow in the image is the fabella, a sesamoid bone found in the tendon of the lateral head of the gastrocnemius muscle behind the knee.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial head of gastrocnemius: This is the muscle on the inner side of the calf; the fabella is never embedded here.

 

Option C. Popliteal artery: This vessel runs behind the knee joint, deep to the gastrocnemius muscle. It is continuation of Femoral Artery.

 

Option D. Adductor longus: A muscle of the medial thigh compartment, unrelated to Fabella.

choices.text: Supplied by sacral nerves S3 and S4 and pudendal nerve

questions.text: All of the following are true about structure marked A except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Attached to pelvic brim

 

Structure A is the levator ani muscle group. It is not attached to the pelvic brim , it attaches to the obturator fascia and arcus tendineus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supplied by sacral nerves S3 and S4 and pudendal nerve: It is supplied by S3, S4, and the pudendal nerve.

 

Option B and C. Converge downwards and medially and Consists of iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus: The fibers converge downward and medially, and it consists of iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus.

 

Labelling of image is given below:

 

A: levator ani muscle

 

B: External Anal Sphincter

 

C: Obturator Internus

 

D: Perianal Fascia

choices.text: Superior segment of right lower lobe
Anterior segment of right upper lobe

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the lung is affected when there is aspiration in supine position?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superior segment of right lower lobe

 

When a patient aspirates in the supine position, the superior segment of the right lower lobe is most commonly affected. This is anatomically the most dependent segment due to the orientation of the bronchial tree in a lying-down position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lingula: Part of the left upper lobe, analogous to the right middle lobe, not a common aspiration site in supine position.

 

Option C. Anterior segment of right upper lobe: More affected in upright aspiration due to gravity, not in supine position.

 

Option D. Right middle lobe: Frequently affected in upright aspiration but less so in supine; not as dependent as the superior segment of the lower lobe when supine.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female presents with chronic fatigue, weight loss, and hyperpigmentation. Her laboratory investigations are given below. Which is the source of the affected structure?

 

Na+ : 118 mEq/L

 

K+: 5.5 mEq/L

 

Cortisol: low

 

Aldosterone: low
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intermediate mesoderm

 

The patient has Addison’s disease (primary adrenal insufficiency) → characterized by:

 

  • Low cortisol (glucocorticoid deficiency → fatigue, weight loss).
  • Low aldosterone (mineralocorticoid deficiency → hyponatremia, hyperkalemia).
  • Hyperpigmentation (↑ACTH → ↑MSH activity due to lack of cortisol feedback).

 

The adrenal cortex is the affected structure here, and its embryological source is:

 

  • Adrenal cortex → Intermediate mesoderm (same origin as kidneys and gonads).

 

[Note: Adrenal medulla → Neural crest cells (gives rise to chromaffin cells).]

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paraxial mesoderm: Forms somites → axial skeleton, skeletal muscles, dermis.

 

Option C. Lateral plate mesoderm: Splits into parietal and visceral mesoderm → body wall, heart, blood vessels.

 

Option D. Neural crest cells: Give rise to adrenal medulla (chromaffin cells), not cortex.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of the same class of glands as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Meibomian glands

 

The histology image shows a sebaceous gland associated with a hair follicle:

 

  • These are holocrine glands, where the entire cell disintegrates to release its secretory product (sebum).
  • The secretion lubricates hair and skin.

 

Other examples of sebaceous/holocrine glands include:

 

  • Meibomian (tarsal) glands in the eyelids → secrete oily layer of tear film.
  • Fordyce spots (ectopic sebaceous glands)
  • Prepuce of Penis
  • Zeiss glands of eyes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mammary gland: Modified apocrine gland (secretion is apocrine + merocrine), not holocrine.

 

Option B. Ceruminous gland: Modified apocrine sweat gland in external auditory canal, produces earwax.

 

Option C. Sweat gland:

 

  • Eccrine sweat glands → merocrine type;
  • Apocrine sweat glands → apocrine type.
  • Not holocrine.

questions.text: Identify the branch of the structure marked ‘a’ in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Radial recurrent artery

 

The image shows a dissection of the forearm, with the structure marked ‘a’ being the radial artery.

 

  • The radial recurrent artery is an early branch of the radial artery.
  • It ascends proximally to anastomose with the radial collateral branch of the profunda brachii artery around the elbow joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior interosseous artery:

 

  • Branch of the common interosseous artery (from the ulnar artery).
  • Runs along the anterior surface of the interosseous membrane.

 

Option B. Anterior ulnar recurrent artery:

 

  • Branch of the ulnar artery.
  • Ascends to anastomose with the inferior ulnar collateral artery.

 

Option C. Posterior interosseous artery:

 

  • Branch of the common interosseous artery (from the ulnar artery).
  • Runs posteriorly through the interosseous membrane.

choices.text: Mesencephalic nucleus - Proprioception from muscles of mastication
Principal sensory nucleus - Touch from face
Special visceral efferent - Muscles of mastication

questions.text: Identify the incorrect pair of function with trigeminal nucleus:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spinal nucleus - Touch from neck

 

  • Function: Pain and temperature sensation from face (not touch from neck). 
  • Extends down to C2–C3 spinal cord levels.

 

The trigeminal sensory nuclei extend through the brainstem and subserve different modalities:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.Mesencephalic nucleus: Function: Proprioception (from muscles of mastication, TMJ, teeth, and periodontal ligaments).

 

Option B. Principal (chief) sensory nucleus: Function: Fine touch, vibration, and pressure from the face.

 

Option D. Special visceral efferent-Muscles of mastication: Function: Motor innervation to muscles of mastication (masseter, temporalis, medial & lateral pterygoid) and a few others (tensor tympani, tensor veli palatini, mylohyoid, anterior belly of digastric).

questions.text: A 6-year-old child falls from his bicycle and injures his hand. On X-ray, a fracture of the first metacarpal bone is noticed. Where is the epiphysis of the affected bone?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) At the base

 

The first metacarpal (thumb metacarpal) is unique compared to the other metacarpals:

 

  • For 2nd–5th metacarpals → the epiphysis is located at the head (distal end).
  • For the 1st metacarpal (thumb) → the epiphysis is located at the base (proximal end).

 

This difference is clinically important when evaluating growth plate injuries in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. At the neck: Epiphysis is never located at the neck region.

 

Option C. At the head: True for 2nd–5th metacarpals, but not for the 1st metacarpal.

 

Option D. In the shaft: The shaft contains the diaphysis, not the epiphysis.

questions.text: Identify the tissue from the histology appearance:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thymus

 

The tissue shown in the image is thymus. The characteristic histological feature seen here is the Hassall's corpuscle (concentric keratinized epithelial reticular cells), which is found only in the medulla of the thymus.
