They are eosinophilic and may show keratinization in older individuals. These structures are unique to the thymus and play a role in T cell development and maturation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spleen: Spleen does not have Hassall’s corpuscles. It contains White Pulp and Red pulp.

 

Option C. Prostate: Prostate contains prostatic glands and Corpora amylacea

 

Option D. Urinary bladder: Urinary bladder shows transitional epithelium. Beneath this is a lamina propria of connective tissue, followed by a thick muscularis layer (detrusor muscle) composed of interlacing smooth muscle bundles.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the emergency room after she sustained a supracondylar fracture of the humerus with injury to the structure marked as 'A' in the given image. Which of the following is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abduction of thumb

 

The marked structure 'A' in the image is the median nerve. Injury to the median nerve at the level of the supracondylar humerus fracture most commonly affects abduction of the thumb (thenar muscle: abductor pollicis brevis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adduction of thumb: Done by adductor pollicis (ulnar nerve).

 

Option C. Flexion of little finger: Flexor digiti minimi (ulnar nerve).

 

Option D. Abduction of little finger: Abductor digiti minimi (ulnar nerve).

questions.text: Given is a model of embryological development of the heart. Which structure develops from the area marked with red arrow?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right ventricle

 

The area marked by the red arrow in this embryological heart development diagram represents the bulbus cordis region. The bulbus cordis, marked by the red arrow, is a vital embryonic region in heart development. It ultimately forms the outflow tract and most of the right ventricle in the adult heart. Abnormal development of this region can result in congenital heart defects involving the right ventricle or outflow tracts.

 

Right ventricle develops primarily from the proximal part of the bulbus cordis. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aorta: Aorta and pulmonary artery develop from the truncus arteriosus. 

 

Option B. Left Ventricle: LV develops from the primitive ventricle which mainly becomes the left ventricle, contributing its muscular wall and cavity.

questions.text: Identify the tributaries of the vessel marked in the image except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Left 5th posterior intercostal vein

 

The vessel marked in the image is the azygos vein. The left 5th posterior intercostal vein (D) is a tributary of the hemiazygos or accessory hemiazygos vein, not the azygos vein.

 

Azygos vein tributaries are:

 

  • Right ascending lumbar vein[A]
  • Right subcostal vein[B]
  • Right posterior intercostal veins[C] (e.g., right 5th)

questions.text: At which level does the nerve supply for the marked structure arise?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aqueduct of Sylvius

 

The labelled structure in the CT is the medial rectus muscle.

 

Step 1: Identify the nerve supply of medial rectus muscle

 

  • The medial rectus is one of the extraocular muscles.
  • It is supplied by the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III).
  • Function → adduction of the eyeball (moves eye medially).

 

Step 2: Nucleus of origin

 

  • The oculomotor nucleus is located in the midbrain.
  • Specifically, at the level of the superior colliculus / Aqueduct of Sylvius.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subthalamic nuclei: Belong to basal ganglia (motor control circuits).

 

Option C. Decussation of pyramidal tract:Located in the medulla (lower brainstem), where corticospinal fibers cross.

 

Option D. Thalamus: Relay center for sensory information (especially VPM for trigeminal, LGN for vision, MGN for hearing).

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of smoking and hypertension presents to the clinic with difficulty swallowing and hoarseness. On examination, he has a decreased gag reflex and asymmetry of the soft palate with uvula deviating to the left upon phonation. These findings suggest a lesion in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nucleus Ambiguus

 

The nucleus ambiguus is located in the medulla and contains branchial motor (special visceral efferent) fibers.

 

  • It supplies motor innervation via cranial nerves IX, X, and cranial part of XI to:
    • Muscles of pharynx (except stylopharyngeus by CN IX, palatoglossus by CN X).
    • Muscles of soft palate (except tensor veli palatini by CN V3).
    • Muscles of larynx.

 

Clinical findings in this patient:

 

  • Dysphagia (difficulty swallowing) → pharyngeal muscle paralysis.
  • Hoarseness → laryngeal muscle paralysis (CN X).
  • Decreased gag reflex → loss of motor limb (CN X via nucleus ambiguus).
  • Uvula deviation to the left → lesion on the right nucleus ambiguus or right vagus nerve, since the uvula deviates away from the lesion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoglossal nucleus:

 

  • Supplies tongue muscles.
  • Lesion → tongue atrophy & deviation (not uvula).

 

Option B. Nucleus solitarius:

 

  • Sensory nucleus (visceral afferents).
  • Involved in taste (CN VII, IX, X) and visceral sensation.

 

Option D. Dorsal motor nucleus of vagus:

 

  • Parasympathetic nucleus of CN X.
  • Controls thoracic/abdominal viscera, not palate or laryngeal muscles.

questions.text: In which of the following chambers can one palpate a muscular ridge, which is the site of origin of pectinate muscles?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right atrium

 

The pectinate muscles are parallel ridges of myocardium.

 

  • In the right atrium, they are prominent in the anterior wall and especially in the auricle.
  • They originate from a muscular ridge called the crista terminalis, which separates the smooth posterior part of the atrium (sinus venarum) from the rough anterior part.
  • This ridge can be palpated and serves as the site of origin of the pectinate muscles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left atrium: Mostly smooth-walled, except for a few pectinate muscles in the left auricle, but no well-defined crista terminalis like in the right atrium.

 

Option C. Right ventricle: Contains trabeculae carneae (irregular muscular ridges)

 

Option D. Left ventricle: Also has trabeculae carneae, papillary muscles, and chordae tendineae, but no pectinate muscles.

choices.text: The primitive streak develops from epiblast
Levator veli palatini arises from 1st pharyngeal arch.
Fabella develops in the lateral head of gastrocnemius
Celiac plexus is located Anterolateral to aorta

questions.text: All of the following are correct except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Levator veli palatini arises from 1st pharyngeal arch.

 

The levator veli palatini is derived from the 4th pharyngeal arch, not the 1st.

 

  • 1st arch muscles include muscles of mastication (masseter, temporalis, pterygoids), mylohyoid, anterior belly of digastric, tensor tympani, and tensor veli palatini (but NOT levator veli palatini).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The primitive streak develops from epiblast: The primitive streak forms on the epiblast during gastrulation and is responsible for the migration of cells that form the mesoderm and endoderm.

 

Option C. Fabella develops in the lateral head of gastrocnemius: The fabella is a sesamoid bone, commonly found in the tendon of the lateral head of the gastrocnemius.

 

Option D. Celiac plexus is located anterolateral to aorta: The celiac plexus (solar plexus) lies around the origin of the celiac trunk, anterolateral to the abdominal aorta near the T12–L1 vertebral level.

questions.text:
Which among the following statements is true regarding the course of the mandibular nerve?

 

  1. Auriculotemporal nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the temporomandibular joint.
  2. Buccal branch is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the mandibular ramus.
  3. Lingual nerve is a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arcs around the submandibular duct.
  4. Ophthalmic nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arises in the middle cranial fossa.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3

 

Mandibular nerve [Cranial Nerve V3]:

 

The mandibular nerve (V3) is the largest branch of the trigeminal nerve, carrying both sensory and motor fibers. It divides into anterior and posterior divisions after entering the infratemporal fossa.

 

Statement 2. Buccal branch is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the mandibular ramus: True. The buccal nerve (sensory, not to be confused with the buccal branch of facial nerve) is from the anterior division. It passes between the two heads of the lateral pterygoid muscle and emerges behind the mandibular ramus to supply the cheek mucosa and skin.

 

Statement 3. Lingual nerve is a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arcs around the submandibular duct: True. Lingual nerve is a posterior division branch. It passes anteriorly in the floor of the mouth and loops around the submandibular duct.

 

False Statements:

 

Statement 1. Auriculotemporal nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the temporomandibular joint: Auriculotemporal nerve is a posterior division branch of V3, not anterior.

 

Statement 4. Ophthalmic nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arises in the middle cranial fossa: Ophthalmic nerve (V1) is a separate division of the trigeminal nerve, not a branch of V3.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Notochord

 

The marked structure is the notochord, a key feature in early embryonic development.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primitive streak: appears as a linear band of thickened epiblast cells in the caudal region of the embryonic disc. The primitive streak is responsible for gastrulation, leading to the formation of the three germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm.

 

Option C. Neural groove: An invagination in the neural plate that precedes closure to form the neural tube; located dorsal to notochord, not in the midline streak.

 

Option D. Secondary neural plate: Refers to caudal neural development region, especially near the tail bud; not typically seen as a single linear streak like the primitive streak

questions.text: A surgeon inadvertently injured the middle trunk of the brachial plexus while removing a Pancoast tumor. Which of the following nerve functions can be impaired?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thoracodorsal nerve

 

  • Origin: Posterior cord (C6–C8).
  • Course: Runs along posterior wall of axilla, accompanying the thoracodorsal artery to the latissimus dorsi muscle.
  • Since posterior cord is partly formed by posterior division of the middle trunk (C7), injury to the middle trunk could impair thoracodorsal nerve function → weakness of latissimus dorsi.
  • Function: Innervates latissimus dorsi, which extends, adducts, and medially rotates the arm; also aids in climbing and swimming motions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial pectoral nerve:

 

  • Origin: Medial cord of brachial plexus (C8–T1).
  • Course: Pierces the pectoralis minor, then supplies both pectoralis minor and pectoralis major.
  • Function: Assists in adduction and medial rotation of the arm.
  • Relation to middle trunk: It comes from the medial cord, which is derived from the anterior division of the lower trunk (C8–T1). Therefore, an isolated injury to the middle trunk (C7) does not affect it.

 

Option B. Nerve to subclavius:

 

  • Origin: Upper trunk of brachial plexus (C5–C6).
  • Course: Descends in front of brachial plexus and subclavian vessels to reach the subclavius muscle.
  • Function: Supplies the subclavius muscle, which stabilizes the clavicle and protects subclavian vessels.
  • Relation to middle trunk: This is a branch of the upper trunk, not middle, so it remains unaffected.

 

Option C. Suprascapular nerve:

 

  • Origin: Upper trunk of brachial plexus (C5–C6).
  • Course: Passes laterally and posteriorly through the suprascapular notch beneath the superior transverse scapular ligament.
  • Function: Innervates supraspinatus (abduction of arm) and infraspinatus (lateral rotation of arm).
  • Relation to middle trunk: Since it is a direct branch of the upper trunk, it is unaffected by middle trunk injury.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy was diagnosed with urethral stricture. He underwent visual internal urethrotomy in the lithotomy position with stirrups supporting both popliteal fossa and proximal parts of tibia. No ankle support was used. On the first postoperative day, the patient complained of decreased sensation on the lateral aspect of right leg, the lateral border of his right foot and difficulty in dorsiflexion of the right foot due to compression of a particular nerve of the lower limb. Which of the following muscles is supplied by the nerve involved in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Extensor Digitorum Longus

 

This boy underwent surgery in lithotomy position with stirrups at the popliteal fossa and tibia, no ankle support → leading to compression of the common peroneal (fibular) nerve around the neck of the fibula.

 

  • Clinical findings:
    • Sensory loss: lateral leg and lateral border of foot (superficial peroneal + sural territory).
    • Motor deficit: difficulty in dorsiflexion of foot (foot drop) → deep peroneal nerve palsy.
  • The extensor digitorum longus is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve, a branch of the common peroneal nerve, hence it is affected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flexor Hallucis Longus:

 

  • Supplied by tibial nerve (posterior compartment of leg).
  • Not affected in common peroneal nerve injury.

 

Option B. Abductor Hallucis: 

 

  • Supplied by medial plantar nerve (branch of tibial nerve).
  • Not affected.

 

Option D. Semimembranosus: 

 

  • Supplied by tibial part of sciatic nerve (posterior thigh).
  • Not affected in isolated common peroneal nerve compression.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the clinic with symptoms of urinary incontinence. She reports a sensation of urgency followed by involuntary loss of urine. Her medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Upon further evaluation, you consider the role of the detrusor muscle in her condition. In understanding the embryological origins of muscles, which of the following muscles is not derived from the paraxial mesoderm?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Detrusor

 

Muscles develop from different mesodermal sources:

 

  • Paraxial mesoderm → forms somites → gives rise to most skeletal muscles of the body.
  • Prechordal mesoderm + paraxial mesoderm (head region) → muscles of the face, pharynx, tongue, and extraocular muscles.
  • Splanchnic (lateral plate) mesoderm → gives rise to smooth muscles of viscera, cardiac muscle, and blood vessels.

 

The detrusor muscle of the bladder is smooth muscle, hence derived from splanchnic (lateral plate) mesoderm, not paraxial mesoderm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Genioglossus:

 

  • A tongue muscle.
  • Derived from occipital myotomes of paraxial mesoderm.

 

Option B. Superior oblique:

 

  • An extraocular muscle.
  • Derived from preotic somites (paraxial mesoderm).

 

Option C. Biceps:

 

  • A skeletal muscle of the limb.
  • Derived from paraxial mesoderm (somites → limb bud mesenchyme).

questions.text: Fourth-year medical students are recruited for a research study assessing their ability to interpret biopsy samples obtained during routine clinical practice. As part of the study, they are given samples of normal respiratory mucosa and asked to identify the cell types present after staining with hematoxylin and eosin. The students observe that the respiratory epithelium changes in composition as the airways continue distally from the trachea to the alveolar ducts. Which of the following features is last to disappear?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cilia

 

The respiratory epithelium and supporting structures progressively change from the trachea → bronchi → bronchioles → terminal bronchioles → respiratory bronchioles → alveoli.

 

Sequence of disappearance:

 

  1. Cartilage – present in trachea and bronchi, but absent in bronchioles.
  2. Mucous glands – submucosal glands decrease and disappear in smaller bronchioles.
  3. Goblet cells – present in bronchi, decrease in terminal bronchioles, and absent beyond.
  4. Cilia – persist the longest, extending into the respiratory bronchioles (help move mucus and debris upward in the mucociliary escalator).

choices.text: Tail of spence extends across anterior axillary fold.
Inner quadrants of breast contain the most breast tissue
The suspensory ligaments of cooper's ligaments are found in the lower part of breast.
Breast is made up of 10 lobes

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the anatomy of the breast?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tail of spence extends across anterior axillary fold

 

The Tail of Spence (axillary tail) is an extension of breast tissue that passes superolaterally across the anterior axillary fold into the axilla.
It is clinically significant because carcinoma of the breast can spread into the axilla via this tail.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inner quadrants of breast contain the most breast tissue: This is false. The upper outer quadrant contains the greatest amount of breast tissue including the tail of Spence. This is also the most common site of breast carcinoma.

 

Option C. The suspensory ligaments of Cooper’s ligaments are found in the lower part of breast: This is false. Cooper’s ligaments are fibrous bands extending throughout the breast, connecting the dermis of the skin to the pectoral fascia, not just the lower part. Their infiltration by carcinoma causes skin dimpling.

 

Option D. Breast is made up of 10 lobes: This is false. The breast typically consists of 15–20 lobes, each drained by a lactiferous duct opening at the nipple.

questions.text: What is the outer covering of the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Amnion

 

The condition shown in the image is omphalocele. In omphalocele, the herniated abdominal contents are covered by a sac composed of amnion on the outside and peritoneum on the inside.

 

Omphalocele is a congenital abdominal wall defect in which the intestines and sometimes other abdominal organs herniate into the base of the umbilical cord. These herniated contents are enclosed in a sac, with the sac's outermost layer formed by the amnion and its innermost layer by peritoneum. This distinguishing feature helps differentiate omphalocele from gastroschisis, where there is no covering sac over the herniated organs

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoderm: The endoderm is the innermost germ layer formed during embryogenesis. It gives rise to the epithelial lining of the gastrointestinal and respiratory tracts, as well as organs like the liver and pancreas. It does not contribute to the outer covering of omphalocele, which is made of amnion.

 

Option B. Ectoderm: Ectoderm forms the outermost layer of the embryo and differentiates into structures such as the skin, hair, nails, and nervous system. It is responsible for creating the body's external surfaces, but not the sac around the omphalocele. The covering of omphalocele is derived from fetal membranes, not ectoderm.

 

Option C. Chorion: The chorion is an extraembryonic membrane formed from trophoblast and mesoderm, and is a component of the placenta. It surrounds the embryo and contributes to nutrient and gas exchange but does not make up the sac covering omphalocele contents. The omphalocele sac specifically has an amniotic outer layer and peritoneal inner layer.

questions.text: In the cross section given below, locate the vagus nerve:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) D

 

In this cross section at the level of neck, the vagus nerve is labeled as D.

 

In given diagram:

 

  • Vagus descends vertically in neck in carotid sheath.
  • Between internal jugular vein & internal carotid artery to upper border of thyroid cartilage.
  • Continues passing between internal jugular vein & internal carotid artery to neck root.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient presents with sudden-onset facial weakness and drooping on one side of the face. The patient also complains of drooling while eating, likely due to weakness in a muscle. Which of the following structures does not pierce the involved muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Buccal branch of facial nerve

 

The muscle involved in this case is the buccinator, which is affected in facial nerve palsy. Buccinator weakness causes drooling and food accumulation in the vestibule of the mouth.

 

The buccal branch of the facial nerve, however, does not pierce the buccinator. Instead, it supplies the buccinator from its superficial surface and lies outside the muscle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Buccal branch of mandibular nerve: Sensory nerve from the anterior division of V3. It pierces the buccinator to supply mucosa and skin of the cheek.

 

Option C. Parotid duct: Traverses across the masseter, turns medially, and pierces the buccinator to open opposite the second upper molar tooth.

 

Option D. Molar mucous glands: Their ducts also pierce the buccinator muscle to open into the vestibule of the oral cavity.

questions.text: Which of the following is related to the marked area in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stomach

 

The marked area in the image of the left kidney is related to the stomach.

 

 

The diagram shows the anterior relation of kidney:

 

 

The anterior relations of the left kidney involve various structures, including the stomach, spleen, and pancreas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spleen: The spleen is typically located more to the left side of the abdomen, and it is not a direct anterior relation of the left kidney. However, there may be some variability in the position of the spleen, and in some individuals, a small part of the spleen might be located anterior to the left kidney.

 

Option C. 2nd part of duodenum: The second part of the duodenum runs horizontally and is situated anterior to the right kidney, it has no relation to the left kidney. This part of the duodenum is part of the foregut and is involved in the digestion and absorption of nutrients.

 

Option D. Pancreas: Pancreas in general is related to the left kidney but below the level of relation with stomach. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stomach is located anterior to the left kidney. The part of the stomach that lies in close proximity to the left kidney is the lesser curvature, specifically the anterior aspect of the stomach. The left kidney is situated posterior to this portion of the stomach.

questions.text: A 44 yr old female presents to the OPD with high grade fever, pain that is constant, throbbing, and worse when sitting down with history of constipation in the past. Fluctuation is noted near the anal region. The Resident decides to drain the ischioanal abscess. Which of the following structures can be injured while draining the ischioanal abscess?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inferior rectal nerve

 

The ischioanal fossa is a fat-filled wedge-shaped space on either side of the anal canal. Infections in this region can lead to an ischioanal abscess, which requires surgical drainage.

 

  • The inferior rectal nerve (branch of the pudendal nerve) crosses the ischioanal fossa to supply the external anal sphincter and skin around the anus.
  • During surgical drainage of an ischioanal abscess, this nerve is at risk of injury, which may result in sensory loss around the anal margin and weakness of the external anal sphincter.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pudendal nerve: Runs in the pudendal canal (Alcock’s canal) along the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa. It is deeper and protected, so less likely to be injured during routine drainage.

 

Option C. Internal pudendal artery: Accompanies the pudendal nerve in Alcock’s canal. Like the pudendal nerve, it is deeper and less likely to be injured directly during drainage.

 

Option D. Posterior labial nerve: A branch of the perineal nerve (from pudendal). Supplies skin of posterior part of labia. Not directly endangered during ischioanal abscess drainage.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles are supplied by the lateral plantar nerve?

 

  1. Abductor hallucis
  2. Flexor digitorum accessorius
  3. Flexor hallucis brevis
  4. First lumbrical
  5. First interossei
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 5

 

The tibial nerve divides into the medial plantar nerve and lateral plantar nerve after passing beneath the flexor retinaculum. Their distributions differ:

 

Medial plantar nerve supplies:

 

  • Abductor hallucis
  • Flexor hallucis brevis
  • Flexor digitorum brevis
  • First lumbrical

 

 

Lateral plantar nerve supplies:

 

  • Flexor digitorum accessorius (quadratus plantae)
  • Abductor digiti minimi
  • All interossei (dorsal and plantar)
  • Lumbricals 2–4
  • Adductor hallucis
  • Lateral head of flexor hallucis brevis

 

 

Checking the options:

 

  1. Abductor hallucis → medial plantar nerve (not lateral).
  2. Flexor digitorum accessorius → lateral plantar nerve.
  3. Flexor hallucis brevis → medial plantar (medial head) and lateral plantar (lateral head).
  4. First lumbrical → medial plantar nerve.
  5. First interossei → lateral plantar nerve

questions.text: Which of the following is not a derivative of neural crest cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retinal pigment epithelium

 

Neural crest cells contribute extensively to structures in the eye as well as the rest of the body.

 

Neural crest derivatives in the eye:

 

  • Corneal stroma and endothelium
  • Sclera
  • Choroid
  • Ciliary muscles
  • Ciliary ganglion
  • Iris stroma
  • Ganglion cell layer of retina

 

Not derived from neural crest:

 

  • Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and neural retina → these arise from the neuroectoderm of the optic cup, not from neural crest.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with condition shown below:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenocarcinoma of bladder

 

The image shows classical features of bladder exstrophy, with exposure of the urinary bladder mucosa in a newborn. This congenital anomaly is strongly associated with an increased risk of adenocarcinoma of the bladder in later life due to chronic irritation and mucosal changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Omphalocele: This is a congenital abdominal wall defect with herniation of abdominal contents into the umbilical cord, covered by a sac. It does not present with exposed bladder mucosa or lower midline defects as seen here.

 

Option C. Persistent vitellointestinal duct (vitelline fistula): This would present with a connection between the ileum and the umbilicus, leading to fecal discharge at the umbilicus, not bladder exposure.

 

Option D. Hypospadias: This is an abnormal ventral opening of the urethral meatus on the penis, not a midline lower abdominal defect with exposed bladder mucosa.

questions.text: Which of the following bones violates ‘The secondary ossification center that appears first, fuses last’ law?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibula 

 

There is a general rule in skeletal development:
“The secondary ossification center that appears first is the one that fuses last.”

 

Fibula: The secondary center at the distal end appears before the proximal one, but it fuses earlier. This is the classic exception to the law
This helps in determining growth patterns and forensic age estimation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radius: Distal end ossifies first and fuses last → follows the rule.

 

Option C. Ulna: Distal end ossifies first and fuses last → follows the rule.

 

Option D. Sternum: Sternebrae ossify and fuse late, generally following the rule.

questions.text:
Arrange the following events of pre-embryonic development in order, from the earlier stage to the later stage:

 

  1. Cavitation
  2. Compaction
  3. Implantation
  4. Cleavage
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4 - 2 - 1 - 3

 

The correct chronological order for these events in pre-embryonic development is:

 

  • Cleavage (4)
    • Immediately after fertilization, the zygote undergoes rapid mitotic divisions.
    • Results in blastomeres without increasing the overall size of the embryo.
  • Compaction (2)
    • At around the 8-cell stage, blastomeres tightly adhere to each other via tight junctions.
    • This forms the morula.
  • Cavitation (1)
    • Fluid begins to accumulate inside the morula, creating the blastocoel.
    • The structure is now called a blastocyst.
  • Implantation (3): The blastocyst embeds itself into the endometrium (around day 6–7).

questions.text: Which of the following descending tracts in the spinal cord remains uncrossed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vestibulospinal tract 

 

  • Origin: Vestibular nuclei in medulla and pons.
  • Remains largely uncrossed.
  • Controls extensor tone and maintains balance/posture.
  • Uncrossed → correct answer.

 

Most descending motor tracts in the spinal cord cross (decussate) at some point, but a few remain uncrossed to ensure bilateral control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tectospinal tract:

 

  • Origin: Superior colliculus of midbrain.
  • Crosses immediately in the dorsal tegmental decussation.
  • Controls reflex head movements to visual/auditory stimuli.
  • Crossed.

 

Option B. Rubrospinal tract:

 

  • Origin: Red nucleus of midbrain.
  • Crosses almost immediately in the ventral tegmental decussation.
  • Facilitates flexor muscles.
  • Crossed.

 

Option D. Pyramidal tract (corticospinal tract):

 

  • Origin: Motor cortex.
  • About 80–90% cross at the pyramidal decussation (lateral corticospinal tract).
  • Remaining 10–20% stay uncrossed as anterior corticospinal tract but eventually cross near the level of termination.

 

Thus, not considered completely uncrossed.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a history of tobacco chewing presented with a non-healing ulcer over the tip of the tongue. Biopsy revealed squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following would be the sentinel lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Submental lymph nodes

 

The lymphatic drainage of the tongue is highly site-specific and clinically important in cases of carcinoma.

 

  • Tip of the tongue → drains first into the submental lymph nodes (sentinel nodes).
  • Lateral anterior 2/3 of tongue → drains mainly into submandibular lymph nodes.
  • Medial anterior 2/3 of tongue → drains bilaterally into deep cervical lymph nodes, especially jugulo-omohyoid.
  • Posterior 1/3 of tongue → drains directly into jugulo-digastric (upper deep cervical) nodes.

 

Thus, in carcinoma at the tip of tongue, the submental nodes are the sentinel lymph nodes.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle causes opening of laryngeal inlet?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroepiglotticus

 

The laryngeal inlet (aditus laryngis) is the opening between the pharynx and the larynx. Its size is regulated by small intrinsic laryngeal muscles.

 

Thyro-epiglotticus:

 

  • A small muscle derived from the thyroarytenoid.
  • Function: widens the laryngeal inlet by depressing the epiglottis and dilating the vestibule.
  • Hence, it is responsible for opening of the laryngeal inlet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocalis:

 

  • A part of thyroarytenoid muscle.
  • Adjusts tension of the vocal cords for fine-tuning of voice.
  • Does not act on the laryngeal inlet.

 

Option C. Cricoarytenoid:

 

  • Refers generally to posterior and lateral cricoarytenoid muscles.
  • Posterior cricoarytenoid: abducts vocal cords (only muscle that opens the rima glottidis, not the laryngeal inlet).
  • Lateral cricoarytenoid: adducts vocal cords.
  • Neither directly opens the inlet.

 

Option D. Thyroarytenoid:

 

  • Relaxes vocal cords and narrows the laryngeal inlet.
  • Opposite of inlet opening.

questions.text: Following are 2 histology slides of types of bone. Which of the following statements are correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-Cortical bone, B-Cancellous bone

 

Image A (first slide):

 

  • Shows concentric lamellae with Haversian canals and osteocytes in lacunae.
  • This is the classical structure of compact bone (cortical bone, Haversian system/osteon).

 

Image B (second slide):

 

  • Shows irregular trabeculae of bone with large intervening spaces filled with marrow.

 

This is typical of spongy bone (cancellous bone, trabecular bone).
